ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 1x every 2 weeks (if that).
zero
Less than 1
1 hour seminar only during the weeks in which seminars were held
0 hours per week
none
2 hours

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Some of the speakers were interesting but some were less so.
I enjoyed hearing from different speakers at each seminar.
The talks were usually interesting and appreciated.
There were much less times of seminars this semester than I expected, I really hoped to hear more from the faculty's research studies.
Great variety of speakers
I like having a lecture series about CDE research, it's really interesting and gave me ideas about who I might want to work with and how to structure my own research practice in the future.
Good, some speakers were a lot better than others.
There were a variety of presenters. I would prefer more frequent seminars.
Great- I love hearing/learning about various research topics in CDE and getting the chance to meet faculty/researchers from other schools and institutions.
It would be helpful to get reminders of when the class is taking place, since there wasn't a regular schedule.
Interesting way to learn about different subjects in CDE. I frequently stayed for the SBS lectures as well.
cool talks, good way to get to know what other professors are doing in the school
Good way to meet faculty in our own departments and learn about what they are doing.
good food this semester!
Don't kill people in your experiments. Got it.

Seminar for CDE was only required once a week - I would have liked for there to be more, but also more diversity in topics. Most were very research heavy and would have liked to know more opportunities post-MPH outside academia.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Trace Kershaw  Trace is great!
Instructor: Trace Kershaw  Organizes great guest lecturers
Instructor: Trace Kershaw  He was nice and fun.

Instructor: Trace Kershaw  This was a guest lecture focused class, so we did not really interact with the main instructor. The guest lecturers were interesting though. It would also be useful to see lecturers who represent non-academic settings, as well (ex: non-profits, private sector).
Instructor: Trace Kershaw  n/a
Instructor: Trace Kershaw  Good speaker.
Instructor: Trace Kershaw  a great instructor

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Compared to the other departments it kind of seems like little thought or planning is placed on the SBS seminar.
Enjoyable.
More seminars per semester would be nice.
Would recommend, even for none SBS/CDE students
Low-key lecture series on topics in CDE. Lectures are usually quite interesting and informative.
I think it's so nice that lunch is provided but if you have a food allergy like gluten, one wasn't given much options!
Yes I would recommend- who wouldn't want to learn about great research while eating delicious food?
This class introduces students to the research work of professors in the SBS and CDE departments.
Good lectures. I would recommend it.
interesting to hear about faculty's research, should continue doing it
worth going to hear the short talks and eat free food
Very good exposure to different fields of research within the CDE department.
I would recommend it. It is a really good course for those interested in becoming familiar with the different public health topics that are being researched at YSPH and Yale.
A few lectures were interesting but most were not very exciting or engaging.
Well you have to take it so just be ready to hear things that you either already know or are so obvious you'll have to pinch yourself to make sure you're still at Yale.
great opportunity for student to learn more about research
